ties
most honorable privy Councell

Belgia 1589. July 9.
It may please yo
r
LL. the 2 of this moneth, I
receaved yo
r
LL. letter of
e 19 of June, and
according to that whiche is first required, and is
likewise mentioned in her Ma
ties
letter to the
Gene-
rall states
, I have signified unto them her Hig
hnes
intention, as touching those general Articles w
ch
were sent unto them by their Deputies: and I have
moved them further, aswell by writing, as by worde
of mouth, to suche effect as yo
r
LL. willed, and
may appeere by the Copie heereinclosed, about
e
enlarging of their Deputies Commission, and also
for encreasing their number, if they should thinke
it so expedient. The Generall Articles were not
sent unto me in Frenche, as they were delivered to
the Deputies: and therfore I thought best to referre
them to those, whiche
e Deputies had already re-
ceaved, lest
e difference of translations should
minister occasion of some scruple. In their
Answear, whiche they delivered presently by worde
of mouth, after speciall thankes to her Ma
tie
for
e
singular care which she hath alwaies shewed for
e
welfare of these Contreis, they declared unto me,
at
unles they receaved
e Articles from
me
in Autenticall
forme, as sent unto them expressely from her Ma
tie
they might not otherwise accept them. where-
uppon I signified againe, that
e Autenticall copie
was in Englishe; and so sent unto me: but their
Deputies had receaved them in Frenche, whereto I
was
e willinger to referre them for
e avoiding of
all ambiguitie in
e diversitie of translations.
Nevertheles because they required to have them so
directly from me, I sent for those, whiche for the
more assurance I had in a readines translated;
and delivered them presently: of w
ch
I send
fol.3v
yo
r
LL.
e copie. Moreover they required of me
to knowe her Ma
ties
determination concerning
e
late promises which had bin made unto them, for
the liquidation of
e accountes between her Hig
nes
and them, concerning
e sending hither of
some speciall person of her privy Councell, w
th
whome
they might treat and conclude uppon
e redresse
of all disorders, concerning
e drawing out of
e supernumerarie bandes in
e Cautionary townes,
to be imploied in times of service, Concerning
e keeping of
e Companies of horse and foote c
o
plete,
which was to be perfourmed
e first of June.
And lastly they required to understand whether
her Ma
tie
would be pleased to disavowe by some
publicke declaration the mutinous practises of all
suche as have, w
t
in
e space of these last two yeres,
under pretext of her Hig
nes
service, taken contrary
courses to
e good and benefitte of these contreis.
As touching these particular demandes I lett them
understand, that I had no charge from her Ma
tie
to signifie any thing unto them, Howbeit I did
not dout but of themselves they did consider
that although her Ma
tie
had promised of late, to fi-
nishe all accountes, and to send hither some person
of honorable q
a
litie, w
t
full satisfaction to their other
demaundes: yet
e c
o
ming of their Deputies into
England, did minister just occasion, to surcease from
that course. For considering
e manifold disorders
and daungers wherto their state was reduced, her
Ma
tie
could not but conceave,
at their Deputies
should have bin sufficiently autorised for
e refor-
mation of whatsoever was requisit. But finding
it otherwise, and knowing
at not only those maters
that were mentioned by them, but sundrie others
fol.4r
of speciall moment, aswell in regard of her Ma
tie
as of them, required to be treated of, she thought
that no determination could be better, seing their
deputies were already in place, then to proceede
in suche order, as I had proposed from her Hig
nes
unto them, and was to require in that behalf their
speedy resoluc
o
n. Wherunto they replied, that
they would consider uppon it, and take suche order
as their state would permitte. I thinke
they are purposed to impart
e Articles to their
severall Provinces: whiche can not be done w
t
out
expense of time: and for mine owne part I am
out of hope
at
e Provinces will assent
s
to any
Commission in suche ample sort, as is required, unles
e Articles were to be treated of heere.
Besides
e Generall Articles, I have also receaved
those particular notes, whiche yo
r
LL. will me
to c
o
municat w
t
some persons in privat, for
e
better advancement of
e service: wherein uppon
sight of that Answear, whiche they shall deliver,
I will proceede as carefully as I may, and as
the state of thinges heere will give me leave.
For it fareth otherwise heere, then happely yo
r
LL.
may have thorowly understoode: for that there are
divers in this place,
at grieve exceedingly, to see
e
badde correspondence which is kept w
t
her Ma
tie
and in that respect are very forwarde to putte
their helping handes to effect
e redresse. Howbeit
in suche a time as this of disunion, and in maters
of suche importance, I knowe they dare not enter
into privat c
o
ference w
t
any minister of her Ma
tie
w
t
out
e privitie of some
s
principall actors:
and
that for suche causes as I have delivered M
r
Se-
cretary, and I presume his H. will impart w
t
yo
r
LL., if I have written any thing therein that
fol.4v
is worthy to be signified. Notw
t
standing as muche
in that respect as may be couvertly and conveni-
ently perfourmed, I will not omitte, as opportunities
are offered, to accomplishe to
e uttermost.
Wheras yo
r
LL. doe further require, to have
e
Generall states solicited in
e behalf of those cap-
taines in
England
, w
ch
are of these Contreis, whose
particular griefes I have receaved in writing, it
may please yow to be advertised, that
M
r
Caron
hath travailed heere of late very painfully in
those causes, and is newly remitted for a finall
answear, to
Count Maurice
in
Zeland
: for whiche
he departed above 10 daies since from
e Hage.
wheruppon I thought it behoofull to attend yo
r
fur-
ther direction, uppon yo
r
LL. liking or disliking
of their Answear. Whiche course I am
e willinger
to folowe, for that I am assured, notw
t
standing
that some of those Captaines are most apparantly
wronged, there can not be any sute preferred
to
e states at this present, wherto they will worse
endure to be pressed by her Ma
tie
then
e sute
of those Captaines. As touching my
L. Willoughbies
cause,
Touchinge
e L. Willughby.
whiche is
e last point of yo
r
LL. letter, I hope yow have receaved my proposi-
tion to
e states in
at behalf, and their Answear
unto it, as also my Replie againe, and particular
specification of those pointes, w
ch
they nether have
nor can verifie against him. Since
e delivery
of those pointes, albeit I have earnestly insisted
to knowe their Answear, I could never hitherto
drawe any thing from them but delaies. For by
c
o
ference w
t
divers, and
M
r
Gilpin
in speciall,
who hath bin many times a party, and almost al-
waies present at all those actions, I have bin tho-
rowly informed, that my L. is charged in them
very unjustly. Nevertheles uppon
e instance
whiche I have used again e, uppon
e receat of thes
e
fol.5r
Yo
r
LL. last letters, they have made me Ans-
wear,
at their Deputies in England have all their
papers and notes concerning those causes, and
at
my L. himself hath proposed his owne griefes, and
shalbe answeared by their Deputies: wherof for
at I
have had no notice, nether from my L. nor any
other, I knowe not howe I may proceede any further,
lest perhaps some incongruitie should escape in o
r
doinges, when thinges are dealt in w
t
out mutuall
privitie, whiche wilbe quickly espied and urged
by
e states. Nevertheles I trust we shall con-
curre in substance, w
ch
wilbe sufficient for my L.
discharge.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. July 9. 1589.
